title: Will any four-week average of US field production of crude oil exceed 12 million b/d in 2021?
preds: After discussing with @GMR, I think this is not close to a 1 in 5 event as previously thought. However, I remain cautious that any anomaly spikes this up toward the very end of the year, vaguely speaking.

With estimates for the first 2 weeks supply being 11550 and 11625, the next 2 weeks of the 4 week average would need to be equally higher than 12000. 
Seems exceedingly unlikely to me

8 in 10 times this resolves no, in my judgement but definitely a rise in probability, in my judgement. By the way, I noticed that the font for GJO just changed on my screen with this forecast update. Looks rounder. Looks nice. Am I tripping?

A jump is needed to at least 12mn bbl/d as of 10 December weekly.
Not likely (11.70/+0.1 as of 03 Dec), however, still feasible. Mild late Atlantic hurricane season 2021, which has officially ended in the meantime with no cyclone activity anywhere near the production sites in the GoM region, could make production jump soon, as more wells should be in preparation to be (re-)opened amid higher prices or already in the pipeline. Mixed signals from OPEC+ recently, despite expected over supply from January 2022, the Organization most recently & strangely  warned of price jumps due to short-term supply shortages. Could be an attractive opportunity to jump in to fill that gap and refill depleting strategic reserves.
To date 4 week average had not exceeded this average and unlikely to do so in the last 4 weeks of 2021
It's late in the year and production is not there

L48 production remains steady, seeing no increase in the last 5 weeks. The four week average value are increasing artificially due to the disruptions in September (and most recently due to a 5k per day increase in Alaska tipping the rounding). Still not anywhere close to on pace for this question to resolve yes.

11/26/21 reported value = 11,500 million b/d. (https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=pet&s=wcrfpus2&f=4). Production will need to increase fairly significantly in the remaining weeks of '21 to exceed 12 million b/d. Overall demand currently seems uncertain and oil prices are falling at the moment. (https://www.reuters.com/markets/commodities/oil-rises-1-ahead-opec-meeting-under-omicron-cloud-2021-12-01/). Maintaining forecast.

Seems increasingly unlikely
11475 was the last weekly estimate
Now there I downward pressure from prices but some will already have momentum

Markets today seem to be pricing the possibility of an overall demand 'hit': https://www.marketwatch.com/story/crude-tumbles-on-fears-of-demand-hit-from-new-covid-variant-as-opec-meeting-looms-for-next-week-11637913584
Again, I have an issue with the word "any."

Although the 4-week average increased by 25, the weekly value dropped 100 from last week. That's moving in the wrong direction to hit the target and virtually makes it impossible to cross the threshold before the question's deadline.
My forecasts have been highly noisy. Not good.

Passage of time update. Also, an analysis of OPEC+ and U.S. shale oil production questions: https://www.forbes.com/sites/daneberhart/2021/11/13/why-are-oil-prices-so-high-when-the-us-remains-one-of-the-worlds-largest-producers/
We have 2 weeks to get over 12m.  Increases are happening but not fast enough.

GoM amounts will add as 2021 Atlantic hurricane season is nearing a calm end. 11,500tbbl weekly reached.
Possible resolution: mid-December.
11,325 last week. Not looking likely, not impossible, just not likely

Could still happen but the window is closing.
Back in 2018 levels were at 11.3m and it took 3 months to get to over 12m.  It had to reach 12m by end Nov to be possible, and that is 5pc increase in one month.
If some large capacity is suddenly turned on due to demand that might make the jump quicker.
Next release 10/11

Current rate in L48 is 11.1 MOPD after holding flat through October. This question cannot resolve to "yes" unless production increases by at least.5 MOPD within the next five weeks and then maintains that rate for four weeks (or the more unlikely scenario that production shoots up in later December weeks after being below 12 MOPD in the beginning). I'll watch closely for the next couple weeks, but this still seems unlikely. Interestingly, the question may resolve based on Alaska production being rounded up or down.  https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/pet_sum_sndw_a_epc0_fpf_mbblpd_w.htm

Increased a bit, probably should go more
Thinking that the announcement that OPEC will not fast track their increase in production will continue to hold prices high and drive up US production. 
4 week average data point make me think that it will head over 11500 again soon with potential to keep climbing but probably not enough time to get there.

Simplistic scenario:  - Production for the four weekly periods reported in October (so far) has increased by about 5.1% overall.  (https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=pet&s=wcrfpus2&f=4) - Part of the early October recovery may be hurricane-affected production coming back. - If reported production increases again by a total of 5% over the next four reporting periods we will reach about 11,900 million barrels per day by around the end of November. If it increases by a total of 4% over the period the late Nov. value would be 11,778. FWIW, my understanding of the question is if any reported 4-week average value (link above) exceeds 12 million barrels (per day) by year-end the forecast would resolve as a 'yes'. https://www.reuters.com/business/energy/oil-prices-march-again-tight-market-us-crude-7-yr-high-2021-10-25/

reminder to myself that if production isn’t at 12m by early Dec, then cannot meet the 4 week average requirement Production back up to 11.4m.  Going right direction as production comes back on line.  Still needs to go up quickly to get there in the next 4 weeks, but increasing forecast a bit.

Reported field production numbers are rapidly increasing since late September, but demand forecasts are currently a little uncertain. Oil prices remain high(er): https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=pet&s=wcrfpus2&f=4, https://www.reuters.com/business/energy/oil-extends-gains-us-crude-inventory-draw-points-strong-demand-2021-10-21/
Brining 1 mln online in 2 months would be fast, but price signals are extremely strong right now and have been. Affirming forecast.

..It may not be "impossible" to achieve a 12 million b/d avg. by the end of 2021. Significant increases have appeared in the last two weekly EIA reports though some of that may be return of production from hurricane-related shut-downs: (https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=pet&s=wcrfpus2)  FWIW: (Excerpt:) "...Production in the Permian Basin of Texas and New Mexico is expected to return to pre-pandemic highs soon. It's being driven this time by private operators, rather than the publicly traded companies that fueled previous booms. Analysts at Rystad Energy forecast production from the Permian will reach its pre-pandemic record high of 4.9 million barrels per day as soon as this month....Meanwhile the public companies have ratcheted back growth. Many are paying off debts, buying back stock and paying dividends rather than reinvesting in new wells." Source: https://hayspost.com/posts/65d94ad7-10c6-4485-9027-2b51bcc43815
Given the recent price increases, I’m baffled that production hasn’t ticked up more.

Just adding forecast with reminder to myself that if production isn’t at 12m by early Dec, then cannot meet the 4 week average requirement.  Production has increased to 10.75 this week, so it’s coming back online, but need to follow how quickly and how far. Looks like numbers are updated fri to fri.

Additional U.S. oil rigs are being added, assuming that's a factor for this question: https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/u.s.-drillers-add-oil-and-gas-rigs-for-fourth-week-in-a-row-baker-hughes-2021-10-01. However, the source cited consistently adds a sentence like this one to its rig update reports: "With oil prices up 56% so far this year, several U.S. energy firms have said they plan to raise spending, which however, remains small as most firms continue to focus on boosting cash flow, reducing debt and increasing shareholder returns." The U.S. EIA somewhat lowered its short-term global oil demand outlook in September (https://www.spglobal.com/platts/en/market-insights/latest-news/oil/090821-us-eia-cuts-2022-global-oil-demand-outlook-by-240000-bd), but oil prices have continued to rise recently, which could possibly help incentivize some new production. U.S. is reportedly considering an SPR release to "cool" gasoline prices: https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/07/oil-markets-us-inventories-demand-concerns.html Staying on the low side for this forecast as U.S. field production still has a fairly long way to go to exceed 12 million b/d before year-end, hurricane season is not over yet, and consumer gasoline demand usually declines some as colder weather arrives : https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=pet&s=wcrfpus2&f=4, https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=pet&s=mgfupus2&f=m

SPR depletion (900k bbl as of 24 Sep 2021)
https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/PET_SUM_SNDW_DCUS_NUS_W.htm Post-hurricane production back at 11,100k (weekly) and rising, due to WTI price not seen in years.

Significant drop off.  But production was at 11.5m and increasing, so quite close to 12m.  If the drop is temporary due to hurricanes it could come back reasonably quickly because it seems demand is there.
Fairly large drop in the latest available 4-week avg., reportedly from Hurricane Ida disruption. https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=49576

While production is creeping up its looking well in line with the EIA forecast so far, and while I can't rule it out completely there's not a lot of news to encourage it crossing 12M for 4 weeks either. The current high for the year is 11.4, which means adding a significant amount in a short period of time. It's not impossible but it's looking far less likely now.

That word "any" irks me. I will raise substantially. "Any" doesn't care about base rates or averages. Additonally, I think using base rates are good for things that are closer to random. This is no random trend, where there are steady rises and falls. And the trend in the last decade is UP. With close proximity, historical trend, a broad restriction, and time in its favor, I am ever so growing my confidence in this may in fact occur. ANYwho...
Hurricane Ida may have at least a short term negative impact on Gulf production. https://texasnewstoday.com/oil-companies-cut-production-in-the-gulf-of-mexico-by-91-ahead-of-hurricane-ida/434835/

Decrease upon realization that declines are more frequent and occur before the cyclical inclines. Also based on simple extrapolation using short-term history and extrapolating/interpolating from past trendlines. I therefore forecast, slightly below the base rate I found. However, still room for noise to bring ANY four-week average to exceed 12k. I'm hedging that 4-week averages are not that prone to noise.

holding fairly steady. covid on the increase at the moment and people leaving their homes less (https://www.usatoday.com/storytelling/coronavirus-reopening-america-map/#restrictions) although restrictions are not coming back on in most states yet.

An increase may occur later this year as forecast and consistent with historical trends. However, the rate of climb needed may be too high. It only takes one data point to resolve this yes. This is going to be a true test of balancing base rates and historical data trends and that intuitive feeling of walking on a tightrope.
I just realized that back in July I was going to reduce to 8 percent and never did. Oh well.
Latest looks to be 11.300.  This is already as high as the projections had for the end of 2021. Going to be optimistic, and say it’s more likely now than it was.

https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=pet&s=wcrfpus2&f=4, plus possible Covid impact on demand, plus this excerpt: "EIA’s most recent monthly data show U.S. crude oil production was 11.2 million b/d in May. We expect production to be relatively flat through October before it starts rising in November and December and throughout 2022. Forecast U.S. crude oil production for 2022 averages 11.8 million b/d, up from 11.1 million b/d in 2021." (https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/)
Counting on relative extremes/noise to resolve this YES. I'm hugging somewhat firmly a base rate for now. Could go wrong because of the phrase "will any."
IEA has downgraded their demand estimate for the end of the year at the same time as Biden has called on OPEC to further increase supply (as if he had some influence over them)
The posted decline in week 1 of August puts the trend way below pace to reach the target.
Some COVID surge (i.e., demand weakness) concerns could have an impact at some point. https://finance.yahoo.com/news/signs-demand-weakness-emerge-oil-190000042.html
One does not need to state the obvious.
One and one sometimes make eleven.
Falling back a bit as this week's numbers came in below the necessary trend line. Production numbers are volatile though, and the leading conditions are in place.

Opec increases agreed to a few weeks ago will damped growth but not stop it.
If we go back to the fast growth of 2019 with 4 years of momentum behind it it took 4 months to go from 11.3m (current level) to 12m. So while it is still possible I think there is too much uncertainty for it to happen now. dropping back down to 10%
Rig counts and production increasing prices holding, maybe possible
Significant uptick of 300k bpd in last 6 weeks. Revising probability up.
Increasing odds as production gains are currently beating forecasts and rig counts are growing.
Reducing a bit more from 14 to 8.
Oil prices pulling back significantly today (part growth concerns and part OPEC+ anouncement of increased supply)

https://www.eia.gov/petroleum/weekly/ “Because changes in rig counts typically lag changes in the WTI price by three to six months and production changes typically occur about two months after rig deployment, current crude oil price levels will not likely affect production until late 2021. We forecast that U.S. crude oil production will average 11.3 million b/d in 4Q21 and rise steadily to 12.2 million b/d in 4Q22, averaging 11.9 million b/d for 2022, up from 11.8 million b/d in the June forecast.” Rig counts remain low: https://m.investing.com/economic-calendar/baker-hughes-u.s.-rig-count-1652/?catPage=history The only thing that worries me is how rapid the acceleration in oil price has been.

Hedging activity means that about 1/3 of the producers don't capture the recent rises in price (and correspondingly don't have the incentive to drill more): https://www.ft.com/content/0d60da9b-54ad-4027-b054-2ff25261e506

Opec+ failure to increase supply and higher prices marginally push probability. The rigs count still looks very very low, but also the output per rig is much higher than historically: https://m.investing.com/economic-calendar/baker-hughes-u.s.-rig-count-1652

COVID decimated American Crude in the Permian Basin and elsewhere. American Crude had been a problem for OPEC and Russia with the gargantuan amount of capital that had been injected into the Permian Basin from 2015 to 2020. Unfortunately, much of these loans and capital were supporting highly levered energy companies that needed an average of $50+ a barrel to survive. The pandemic ended many of them and with that our 13 million b/d average. In the past, when American Crude fumbled in 2015, it took a year to rebuild a million b/d in production. And that was because of the intense capital flows. It took from 2006 to 2012 to increase production 1mil b/d.

Online, the US Energy Information Administration has a dataset of monthly b/d numbers throughout history since 1920. There would be about a .9% growth per month required to reach 12 million b/d by the end of the year. Historically, the average monthly growth rate is .15% per month, and the third quartile of monthly growth rates is about 1.3%. This definitely seems possible, given that production was at 12,000 before the pandemic, but given the new fears of the delta variant may mean oil consumption/demand is not high enough to prompt producers to reach the .9% monthly growth required to reach 12 million b/d.  The US Energy Information Administration projects that the average will be 11.8 million b/d in 2022. There seems to be no evidence that the rate of increase of production will be significantly higher than anticipated.

To get 1000k b/d increase in 6 months has only happened before in 2018/19 at the fastest rate of increase since start of the data in the question link in 1983. There was already 2.5 years of momentum at that point too. currently there is no momentum increase. I was sitting at around 50% for a 2 weeks before I looked into it a bit further today. going to give it a very low score for a few weeks to drop my average a bit quicker. Might increase it again if the price does go up but I doubt it.
Might be an increase if plugged wells are opened with a massive price surge.

You would need a 1000 bpd increase in the next 6 months. An absolute value move that size (to the upside or downside) is about a 2.18 standard deviation event since 2007 (I looked less before then since the oil production picture in the U has changed massively). Using that alone would imply about a 2% chance. However, the US has produced 13 million bpd as late as early 2020 (spare capacity) and oil prices are up significantly. Given that EIA estimates 11 bpd tis year and 11.8 bpd in 2021, I would keep a low probability for exceeding 12 million in 2021, but significantly above what the historical z-score move would imply.  https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/report/us_oil.php
Would need a very fast surge in oil production relative to history
oil price and rig count still rising, still looking possible.
Used the data from the site. I then did a max for 29 interval for a column. Then divided max/weekly price. It was above 1.0909 83 times out of 1968 weeks.

Even as oil prices are rising, oil company stocks are struggling, reflecting the higher cost of capital for private sector fossil fuel companies in the west. Current outlook is for oil production to average 11.1 bpd in 2021 and 11.8 bpd in 2022. Doesn't mean you can't have a 4 week average pop up higher than that, but seems lower probability: https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/

Passed 12bn first time ever in Mar 20. Currently at 10bn or so. Took 6 months to ramp up from 10bn to 12bn in 2019/20.  Unless economy really lights up it doesn’t seem likely that this rate of increase will be matched. There is little sign so far this year of an increase in production.  But the EIA predict 11.6bn for second half that is not far off. And some shock somewhere could hit everything On the other hand opec have loads of capacity and like to manage prices so if they up production it will lower prices and make US production less viable.  Tricky one but shading a bit more likely to no.

Excerpt, quarterly forecast from 6/15/21 EIA article: "We expect crude oil production in the United States will increase each quarter through the forecast period, averaging 11.4 million b/d in the fourth quarter of 2021 (4Q21), the highest level since 1Q20, and 11.1 million b/d for all of 2021." Source: https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=48376
I made this forecast with the Software Prevista PROGNOST.

https://www.spglobal.com/platts/en/market-insights/latest-news/oil/061521-crude-oil-futures-rise-as-jcpoa-restoration-seems-unlikely-in-near-term EDIT:
"It remains unclear how soon the injunction could lead to oil and gas lease sales restarting.[...]
Louisiana, Alaska, Texas, Utah and Oklahoma were among the states that filed the lawsuit and asked for a preliminary injunction, which takes effect immediately and remains in place while litigation proceeds. "
https://www.argusmedia.com/en/news/2225170-us-judge-blocks-biden-pause-on-oil-gas-leasing "Waterborne gasoline loadings out of the US Gulf coast have exceeded pre-pandemic levels in the first half of June for the first time since Covid-19 first took hold in the US last spring."
https://www.argusmedia.com/en/news/2224653-us-gulf-gasoline-exports-top-prepandemic-levels

US has reached this peak before (Feb 2019-april 2020) when covid dropped production. they will reach it again most likely, the question is when. things are returning to normal in US which will drive up demand for oil again. prediction of still less demand for fuel in summer of 2021 vs summer of 2019. and for average of 11.1 M barrels per day over 2021, contrasted to forecast of 11.8 barrels per day in 2022.
https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/archives/jun21.pdf
the barrel numbers seem to be holding fair steady for this year at around 11M aside from a small dip in Feb.
https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=PET&s=WCRFPUS2&f=W
national rig count had dropped from from 876 (2019) to 241 (sept 2020). How long does it take to fire up a rig again? and reemploy all the laid off workers? In May 2021 the number of working rigs had risen to 457, producing 11M barrels. do they need to fire up the extra rigs if they are already meeting demand?
https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2020/09/07/covid-19-us-oil-industry-wyoming-texas-baker-hughes/5735992002/
https://www.statista.com/statistics/1109332/us-oil-and-gas-rigs-in-use-covid19/ EIA predicting price of brent crude to remain the same this year as demand grows and supply catches up to demand but then to fall next year when supply exceeds demand. Price of brent crude is high currently, hence they expect the price to start to drive more rigs to be deployed.
https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/ its a bit hard to call! the year forecast is well below that 12M mark but then it could go over for a 4 week period. I think i'll have to sit in the middle!

The crude price has doubled since Oct 2020, with WTI now at about $71.50.  See https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/CL1:COM?sref=x7nYEkiY.
During this time period the US rig count has increased from 296 to 461.  See https://ycharts.com/indicators/us_rotary_rigs.
During the same time period US 4-week average production has been pretty flat.  See https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=pet&s=wcrfpus2&f=4. With a strong price and more drilling rigs one would have expected an increase in production.  Perhaps demand was a limiting factor.  If so we have the often-cited "summer driving season" beginning right about now.  So a 10% increase in production looks very possible.  I'll give it a 50/50 chance.

Expectations of growth in demand, particularly in US as the country opens up from covid. Expect an increase in consumer and business confidence with expected gdp increases which could lead to more investment in rigs. 
$US is lowest in 5 years which will give confidence to exporters leading to local production.  OPEC expects strong growth but major players (Saudis) have stated that they will wait and see the demand before they risk a production increase. This may lead to US producers bringing wells online faster (3 month end of range rather than 6) as the  price per barrel continues to increase. 
US covid is in good position but some OPEC nations could be in trouble with low vaccination and potential for outbreaks and risks to production.
Lack of international flights could mean more local driving holidays and a higher demand than the pessimistic EIA forecasts. Will be interesting to check trends in 1 month.
Very cognisant that my forecast is higher than crowd. Will need to read more of others justifications and update for counter evidence.

A prima facie cursory reading suggests low odds. Will have a detailed look later.  Found this excerpt quite useful from the EIA June 21 report
We expect that the rig count is likely to continue to increase in response to WTI crude oil prices rising from less than $50/b in late 2020 to a monthly average of $65/b in May. Our models show changes in rig counts typically lag behind changes in the WTI price from between three and six months, and production typically comes online about two months after rig deployment. Assuming that other factors remain constant, price increases over the past month will likely continue to drive rig deployments through much of the rest of 2021. However, the recent changes in rig counts indicate operators, notably in the Permian, could be deploying fewer rigs at current oil prices than they have previously deployed when oil prices were at similar levels.  Just looking at Rig counts however doesnt reveal a full picture - The productivity of new rigs has been improving over the years - https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=36012 Most of the rig additions are happening in the Permian region.  Also need to consider the impact of the Iran deal (if it were to happen)
An agreement between the two sides could see Iran return to its pre-sanction production levels. Iran produced 2.43 million b/d of crude in April, according to the latest S&P Global Platts survey of OPEC output, down from its pre-sanctions production of between 3.8 million-3.9 million b/d.
https://www.spglobal.com/platts/en/market-insights/latest-news/natural-gas/061021-us-oil-gas-rig-count-climbs-8-to-560-on-strong-permian-activity

The predictions call for 11.07 b/d but with the oil prices there is a chance, especially if the Iran deal does not work out.  https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/data/browser/#/?v=3&f=M&s=0&start=201701&end=202212&maptype=0&ctype=linechart&linechart=COPRPUS

I am excited for this one! There is a lot of details that are available and you can easily find yourself spending days trough through. The current EIA forecast has the production below at 11.38 Mbbl/d. Although looking at current oil prices above $70/bbl and their forecast has prices going down to ~$60 for Q4. EIA, like many strip prices are usually slow to adapt to a changes in price. The current oil price should bump up their forecast for Q4 and therefore production numbers should also increase.  In OPECs June Market report they have US crude production going to 11.6 Mbbl/d in December. June has already seen a $5/bbl rise from May in which the OPEC forecast is based off of. With this increased price with the hopes of the world economy reopening, their next month forecast should reflect an uptick based on this optimism.  I also believe with the weakening of the US dollar will increase oil exports. My main worry is that a ~700,000 bbls/d extra in the market will depress prices and won't sustain a 12 Mbbl/d production for 4 weeks. Given the recent optimism with a higher oil price, I believe there is a shot at a 4 week period to be higher than 12 Mbbl/d (67%). This also reflects a large ramp up of completions activity with an oil price that is well above most basins breakeven.  EIA graphing tool (https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/data/browser/#/?v=3&f=M&s=0&start=201701&end=202212&maptype=0&ctype=linechart&linechart=COPRPUS) OPEC Monthly Report (https://www.opec.org/opec_web/en/publications/338.htm)

Currently doesn't seem likely. EIA's domestic production quarterly estimates for the rest of 2021 are below 12 million b/d (https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/archives/jun21.pdf).  All 2021 weekly figures have been 11 million b/d or less so far.  (Seasonal factors may be an influence.) (https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=pet&s=wcrfpus2&f=4) Further, though U.S. demand for petroleum products will likely (continue to) increase in months ahead, ".. ability of producers to respond to increased crude oil demand will be constrained by scarcity of drilling rigs, crews and capital".  More here (link): https://seekingalpha.com/article/4432757-time-to-bet-on-crude-buy-clu1 FWIW: There was a surprising recent 'build' (increase) in U.S. gasoline and distillate inventories, which may be short-term: https://www.spglobal.com/platts/en/market-insights/latest-news/oil/061021-crude-oil-futures-dip-on-large-us-products-build

"We estimate that 2022 production will average 11.8 million b/d, up from a forecast average of 11.1 million b/d in 2021." This would imply crossing 12m in 2022 at least once is probable but the expectation is lower in 2021 "The number of oil and gas rigs in the United States rose this week, bringing the total rig count to 461 as U.S. drillers boast more than 100 additional rigs this year."
"The EIA’s estimate for oil production in the United States for the week ending June 4—the last available data—returned to an average of 11.0 million barrels per day compared to the 13.1 million bpd peak production reached in February 2020, before the pandemic crushed oil demand."
https://oilprice.com/Energy/Crude-Oil/US-Oil-Rig-Count-Rises-As-Crude-Prices-Climb-Higher.html Production first crossed the 12m mark in Feb 2019 and stayed above until April 2020 and hasn't recovered yet. During its most aggressive increases production added 125k b/d per month on average and June is forecast to be 11m b/d. If it matches that rate, which seems plausible, it still puts us into 2022 before crossing 12m. That said higher increases have happened (+500K Oct-Nov 2018) so we have to assume the capacity is there. It doesn't seem likely given prices and forecasts but it's far from impossible. I'm starting with a guess will adjust from there.
Leaning towards no if the numbers haven't climbed already this year.  I think the next month will tell the tale.

Probably not.  2020 and 2021 were going to be reduced years for us oil production as the bull in shale gave out with or without covid.  OPEC won the war and the money backing US shale production walked away. They ain't coming back.  Even if oil spikes to $100 they ain't coming back because OPEC+ will turn on the taps faster than new equipment can get out to the permian basin.
